Award.AwardTitle: Capacious Deep-Cavity Cavitand/Hydrophobic Guest Assemblies with Tunable Interior Volumes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Ashbaugh, Henry
Proposal Number: 1403167
Institution: Tulane University
Title: Capacious Deep-Cavity Cavitand/Hydrophobic Guest Assemblies with Tunable Interior Volumes

The hydrophobic effect (the tendency of nonpolar molecules to separate from water) affects many different fields: the pharmaceutical industry (formulation and drug affinity), life sciences (proteins and macromolecular structures), material sciences (properties of polymers, emulsions, and liposomes), and indeed any chemical engineering or chemical application involving aqueous solutions (e.g., natural gas liquid separations and reactions in aqueous solution). This collaborative proposal aims to advance foundational knowledge of the hydrophobic assembly of cavitands (molecular assemblies that contain a cavity for guest molecules) and quantify the various factors governing their assembly and stability. Achieving the goals of this project will provide valuable information to exploit the class of dimeric, tetrameric, and hexameric assemblies in a range of potential technological applications, such as drug delivery vehicles, using either direct drug encapsulation or entrapment within cavitand/polymer networks. In addition, graduate and undergraduates will gain valuable training in both simulation techniques and experimental experience. The PIs will also incorporate the results of their research into a public service course.

Simulations will be carried out in the Ashbaugh lab to characterize the structures of cavitand/guest assemblies in solution in molecular detail, quantify the thermodynamic driving forces for capsular assembly, and determine the guest binding free energies that drive complex structural transitions with increasing guest size. Experiments will be carried out in the Gibb lab to synthesize cavitands with varying chemical functionalities and pocket sizes, determine the binding affinities of alkyl guests within the cavitand complexes, and characterize the aggregation state of the complex and conformational motifs of confined guests. These tasks will enable the investigators to determine the influence of alkane host size, cavitand chemical structure, and solution conditions on the aggregation state of the cavitand assembly, as well as enable them to determine the molecular structures associated with cavitand assembly.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The adage “oil and water” don’t mix captures the primary feature of the hydrophobic effect. Beyond the adage, the ability to manipulate in the insolubility of oily species on the molecular-level opens up opportunities to control the assembly of molecules in solution to build structures that could be used in a wide range of applications, from drug delivery, to fluid viscosity control, controlled nano-scale reactors, and nanostructured materials. This grant funded an experimental/simulation collaboration to manipulate the assembly of bowl-shaped molecules, referred to a cavitands, into a wide range of structures when bound to oily guests that sit within the bowl, from dimeric capsules, to tetrahedral tetramer, to cubic hexamers. The simulations work provided unprecedented molecular detail to uncover the forces driving cavitand assembly and provide a thermodynamic rationale for the stability of these structures in water. Specific accomplishments include, determining the role of oily guest packing on guiding the assembly of cavitands into dimers, tetramers, and hexamers, and how simple modifications of the cavitand bowl can dramatically impact the assembly properties. This project wasmotivated to determine if molecular simulations could provide a molecular rationale for the experimentally observed cavitand assembly. By the close of the project, the simulations were beginning to guide the experiments performed, permitting the computational design of cavitand assemblies. Specific successes on this front include the prediction that methyl functionalization of the cavitand bowl can drive the hydrophobic dewetting of the bowl in water, and that distinct placements of methyl units about the entrance to the bowl can tip the cavitand assembly properties in a range of directions that can be controlled through synthetic routes.

The results of the supported work apply well beyond cavitand assembly. Specifically, a wide range of assembly processes occur in water, from the stabilization of protein structures, the binding of molecular species (like drugs) to protein binding sites, the formation of lipid membranes, and the assembly of soap into micelles that can be used for environmental clean-up. The rules uncovered for cavitand assembly are similarly applicable to understanding these processes. Moreover, the results found provided key insights into the structure of water, which serves as the stage upon which hydrophobic driven assembly occurs.

Over the lifetime of the project, this grant provided support for four graduate students, working in a collaborative experimental/simulation environment, towards their training for a PhD. Undergraduate students were engaged in this research through summer research projects. Finally, K-12 audiences were engaged in this project through outreach opportunities provided by the class “Chemistry and Engineering Science in the Community”, offered each spring of the project. These efforts ultimately provide support for the pipeline of students to engage in STEM training from the undergraduate to graduate level, building a technically educated workforce.


Last Modified: 08/01/2018
Modified by: Henry S Ashbaugh
